column1: Pleasant Prairie is a village in Kenosha County
column2: Wisconsin situated between Milwaukee and Chicago. The population was 19
column3: 719 at the 2010 census. Among its notable features are the RecPlex
column4: which  is the largest municipal recreational facility in the United States and Chiwaukee Prairie
column5: a coastal wetland of international significance.  The neighborhoods of Carol Beach
column6: Dexter's Corner
column8: and Tobin are located within the village.

column1: The Pleasant Prairie area was the center of Native American activity in pre-pioneer Wisconsin. Some of the earliest traces of Native American life in Wisconsin have been found along State Highway 32 and State Highway 165
column2: Barnes Creek
column3: and in the Carol Beach area. These early Native American campsites were located along what was once the shoreline of Lake Michigan. Pleasant Prairie also saw pioneers arrive in Wisconsin on the Jambeau Trail (now known as Green Bay Road). In addition
column4: several natural historic sites such as the Chiwaukee Prairie and the Kenosha Sand Dunes lie undisturbed in Pleasant Prairie.

column1: The area's first white settler was Horace Woodbridge
column2: who arrived on June 4
column3: 1833; Henry Miller arrived later that same month. Pleasant Prairie had its beginnings as a political entity in April 1842 when the first town meeting was held and the first election of town officials took place. The early town officials met in the Williams Congregational Church located at 93rd Street and Green Bay Road. Later the old church became the town hall. Pleasant Prairie originally was a town nearly 42 square miles (110 km2) in size.

column2: the city of Kenosha began to annex lands south of 60th Street and west from Lake Michigan. The town of Pleasant Prairie was slowly reduced in size as Kenosha grew. There were nine separate settlement areas in the town that in some cases became the starting point for significant growth. Some no longer exist.

column1: The original unincorporated community of Pleasant Prairie was located at 104th Avenue and Bain Station Road. Prior to 1875 it was known as "Tar Corners" because a thief was once tarred and feathered there.
At the dawn of the 20th century
column2: Pleasant Prairie was the site of a 190-acre DuPont blasting powder plant. The plant
column3: made up of 40 buildings
column4: had an ongoing record of accidents. In 1909
column5: residents of Kenosha County brought suit against the company on the grounds that the plant was a public menace. The suit was won by the company.

column3: most of the town was destroyed by the explosion of five magazines holding 300 tons of dynamite
column5: 000 kegs of black blasting powder
column6: and five nearby railcars holding more dynamite housed at the plant. The explosions rendered most houses within five miles of the blast center uninhabitable. Several hundred people were injured
column12: were killed. The low death toll was attributed to the plant being closed at the time of the explosion. A crater 100 feet deep was blasted under the former dynamite house. Damage estimates were put at $1
column17: 000 in 2015. Almost equal damage was done in Bristol
column18: four miles west of Pleasant Prairie.

column1: The force of the explosion was felt more than 130 miles in every direction and was heard as far away as Ohio and Iowa. Many in the Midwest at first believed it was an earthquake. Residents in nearby Lake County
column2: Illinois saw the fireball and remembering the Peshtigo fire fled their houses
column3: jumping into Lake Michigan. Police in Chicago scoured the streets
column4: looking for the site of a bombing. Windows were shattered as far away as Madison
column5: Wisconsin
column6: a distance of some 85 miles. Concerns about looting and vandalism by curiosity seekers prompted Kenosha County Sheriff Andrew Stahl to impress a hundred deputies and clear the village.It was believed the first explosion took place in the glaze house where more than 1
column7: 100 kegs of powder were dried in steel cylinders. One steel cylinder crashed through the roof of the general store of H. A. and E. A. King
column8: tearing a hole five feet in diameter through the roof
column9: the first and second floor and into the earth. H. A. King
column11: was thrown to the floor unconscious by the shock. Phil Hess
column13: Wisconsin over two miles from the factory
column15: severed by a piece of flying glass as he was entering his home. J. H. Beland of Truesdell lost his eye from flying glass
column18: bled heavily when a vein in his wrist was cut.

column1: A DuPont spokesman was reported as being perplexed by the coverage of the blast
column2: quoted as saying "explosions occur every day in steel mills
column3: flouring mills and grain elevators with hardly a line in the paper."Today
column4: the site is the location of residential homes and the Pleasant Prairie Ball Park
column5: which is used for softball and soccer.

column2: the town of Pleasant Prairie struggled to maintain its independence and identity apart from Kenosha
column3: its larger neighbor to the north. In 1961
column4: the village hall moved from the former Williams Congregational Church site to rented office space in a small commercial center located on 22nd Avenue and 91st Street. In 1967 the village government moved into a newly constructed municipal building on Springbrook Road and 39th Avenue that provided office
column5: an auditorium
column6: Fire Department apparatus room

column2: the town and the city of Kenosha agreed upon a plan for the orderly development and fixed boundaries for the town in exchange for an acknowledged right of property owners in various locations along the village/city border to be annexed into the city of Kenosha. A significant provision of this agreement gave Kenosha the ability to annex lands north of State Highway 50 from Green Bay Road to I-94
column3: where the Southport Plaza shopping center
column4: WhiteCaps subdivision
column5: River Crossing subdivision and the Aurora Hospital are located. In exchange
column6: Pleasant Prairie was granted the ability to protect the rest of its area from annexations and to purchase sewer and water from Kenosha.

column2: the town of Pleasant Prairie was incorporated as a village by a referendum of more than 3
column3: 000 citizens in favor and 300 against. The new boundaries were fixed and the new village
column4: along with the WisPark Corporation
column5: began the development of LakeView Corporate Park
column6: a center of employment for more than 8

column2: eight years after the incorporation of the town into a village
column3: the Municipal Building was updated and increased in size to accommodate village operations.

column1: One of the best-known features of Pleasant Prairie is the RecPlex. Covering over 300
column2: 000 sq. ft.
column3: it is the largest municipal recreational facility in the United States. The complex of buildings includes a 50-meter pool
column4: water park
column5: fitness center
column6: field house
column7: suspended track and two NHL-sized ice rinks. The RecPlex is located in Prairie Springs Park and is adjacent to Lake Andrea. The 121-acre lake provides visitors with access to a beach
column8: as well as opportunities to swim

column1: The Chiwaukee Prairie State Natural Area is one of the largest prairie complexes in the state of Wisconsin. It is an assemblage of 485 acres of coastal wetlands and sand dunes that stretch along Lake Michigan from the Illinois state line to the Kenosha Sand Dunes on its northern boundary. Embedded within these natural areas is the residential neighborhood of Carol Beach. Chiwaukee Prairie is home to many species of plants and animals
column2: some of which are endangered. In 2015
column3: Chiwaukee was designated as a Ramsar wetland of international significance.

column2: 400-acre mixed use development that houses manufacturing
column3: distribution
column4: office and service operations in a park-like setting east of I-94. Among the tenants is Jelly Belly
column5: which offers tours of its distribution facility and is a popular destination for visitors. Included in the LakeView development is a 425-acre nature conservancy along the Des Plaines River floodplain. The village has opened a newer 440-acre development called Prairie Highlands Corporate Park just west of I-94. Among the tenants are Haribo
column6: makers of gummy bears

column1: Pleasant Prairie Prime Outlets was opened in 1988
column2: not long before the Original Outlet Mall just to the north closed. Prime Outlets is a large
column3: outdoor shopping center just east of I-94 at the Highway 165 exit
column4: and often lures shoppers from the Chicago area. It has over 90 stores
column5: many of which are factory outlets for major national brands
column6: including Nike
column10: Ann Taylor and Polo Ralph Lauren.

column1: The Village of Pleasant Prairie has no downtown. Early in 2019
column2: the village enlisted a large group of residents to generate ideas for a downtown on 180 acres near the Village municipal building. Residents highlighted the need for relatively dense residential housing
column3: a public market
column4: restaurants and other civic amenities
column5: all while maintaining green spaces and respecting the village's prairie identity. In October 2019
column6: the village signed a contract with Rinka
column8: to develop a master plan for the downtown based on those principles. A draft of the plan was presented to the public in June

column2: -87.870229).According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the village has a total area of 33.64 square miles (87.13 km2)
column4: of which 33.33 square miles (86.32 km2) is land and 0.31 square miles (0.80 km2) is water.

column1: Carol Beach is a residential neighborhood located in Pleasant Prairie. It is generally bordered by Lake Michigan to the east
column2: the Wisconsin-Illinois border to the south
column3: Sheridan Road (Wisconsin State Highway 32) to the west
column4: and the Kenosha Sand Dunes to the north.

column1: Carol Beach traces its roots to 1924
column2: the year that Edith Rockefeller McCormick of Chicago
column3: Illinois
column4: the daughter of John D. Rockefeller and daughter-in-law of reaper inventor Cyrus McCormick
column5: purchased a 1
column6: 554-acre (6 km2) land parcel to found a new community which soon adopted the name "Chiwaukee" (the area is nearly equidistant between Chicago and Milwaukee
column7: Wisconsin). Chiwaukee was to have its own business district
column9: and its homes were to be constructed in the Tudor style. A promotional arch was constructed over Sheridan Road to inform passersby of the new
column10: planned community. A street network was installed
column11: with Lakeshore Drive as the main thoroughfare.

column1: A national contest was announced to select a permanent name for the new community. Elmer Huge of La Porte
column2: Indiana won a $1
column3: 500 prize for his winning submission: "Edithton Beach". Boxing aficionado Ham Fisher
column4: the creator of the "Joe Palooka" strip
column5: moved to a large home on south Lakeshore Drive in Edithton Beach where he drew the series and where famous pugilists (among them Joe Louis) would train.

column2: McCormick's debts mounted and the project collapsed. The curbs and streets leading nowhere were the only visible reminders of the failed project until 1946
column3: when local real-estate investor and developer Joseph Shaffron bought it
column4: renamed it "Carol Beach" for his young daughter
column5: and promoted the community as a "second Evanston
column6: Illinois." Some modest homes began to be built at that time.

column1: The area is one of the most significant wetland areas in the United States and was largely protected through a compromise land use agreement between the Town of Pleasant Prairie
column2: Kenosha County
column3: the State of Wisconsin
column4: and the Army Corps of Engineers. Today many of the areas that can be developed have been
column5: and the state of Wisconsin and the Nature conservancy continue to buy remaining properties for prairie land preservation. These undeveloped tracts of land
column6: including the Kenosha Sand Dunes
column7: constitute the Chiwaukee Prairie. In 1992 the Town of Pleasant Prairie
column8: in which Carol Beach is located
column9: became a village. The neighborhood continues to be known as Carol Beach.

column1: Dexter's Corner is a residential and agricultural community within the village of Pleasant Prairie. It is located at the intersection of Wisconsin Highway 31 and Springbrook Road.The area is named for the pioneer John Dexter family
column2: the patriarch of which was a veteran of the War of 1812. The red-brick Dexter residence is located to the north of the intersection. The site is near the location of a tower for FM radio station WWDV (formerly WKZN and WAXO).

column1: Ranney (also known as Rogers Siding) is a ghost town in Pleasant Prairie. It is located at the intersection of Bain Station Road and the Canadian Pacific Railroad (originally the Chicago
column2: Milwaukee
column3: St. Paul & Pacific Railroad). The last passenger train stopped at the Ranney Station prior to 1862
column4: but the Ranney post office opened in 1885 and lasted into 1906. The Bain Station of the KD Line was located just east of Ranney
column5: and remained into the 1940s. Rogers Siding itself was a KD Line team track just west of Green Bay Road for area farmers who would load their produce for rail shipments; the siding itself was removed in the 1980s. The last house in Ranney
column6: the former KD Line yardmaster's house
column8: and the area is now devoid of all traces of community except for continuing railroad activity on the KD Line and the Canadian Pacific. Much of the property there is now owned by We Energies.

column1: Tobin is an area along 116th Street in Pleasant Prairie.  The community is named for early settler Patrick Tobin. Tobin's most famous visitors included boxer Joe Louis
column2: who would arrive and depart at the Tobin station on the Chicago North Shore and Milwaukee Railway interurban in the mid-1930s
column3: to train at the Ham Fisher mansion in nearby Carol Beach
column4: and to supervise the Joe Louis Boxing Camps held at Lakefront Stadium.
